{{hatnote|Not to be confused with the [[Islamic Education and Research Academy]]: London, United Kingdom}} {{hatnote| or with the [[Islamic Research Foundation]]: Mumbai, India}} {{Infobox organization | name = Islamic Research and Educational Academy | headquarters = 1/29 Dunlop St, [[Hoppers Crossing, Victoria]] | motto = "We use religion to unite, where others may seek to use it to divide" | coordinates = {{coord|-37.868489|144.723442|display=inline,title}} | registration_id = [[Australian Business Number|ABN]] 71161351695<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abr.business.gov.au/SearchByName.aspx?SearchText=Islamic%20Research%20and%20Educational%20Academy|title = ABN 71161351695 }}</ref> | status = Registered with [[Australian Charities and Not-For-Profits Commission |ACNC]] as a charity<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acnc.gov.au/RN52B75Q?ID=C753BE43-3DCC-4255-9978-6B9CA26B69C8&noleft=1 |title= Charity name: Islamic Research and Educational Academy Ltd |date=22 November 2012|work=[[Australian Charities and Not-For-Profits Commission]]|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> | formation = {{start date and age|2012|11|22}} | leader_name = Waseem Razvi | key_people = Syed Murtaza Hussain<ref name = "CT1">{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/antiislam-activist-ayaan-hirsi-ali-protesters-met-with-radical-sheikh-20170406-gvfady.html |title=Anti-Islam activist Ayaan Hirsi Ali protesters met with radical sheikh |author=Maley, Jacqueline|date=8 April 2017|work=[[Canberra Times]]|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> | type = Conservative [[Salafist]]<ref name="IREA"/> | website = http://www.ireaworld.org/ }} {{Islam in Australia}}
The '''Islamic Research and Educational Academy''' (IREA) is an independent Islamic [[dawah]] organisation based in [[Hoppers Crossing, Victoria]]. It has been categorised as 'extremist' by some groups.<ref name = "Melbourne University">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/nsw-act/melbourne-university-hosts-extremist-muslim-group-in-the-wake-of-sydney-shooting/news-story/ef3f4bbabf34db37dabbf70f78de4f65 |title= Melbourne university hosts extremist Muslim group in the wake of Sydney shooting|author=|date=5 October 2015|work=News Ltd|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref> It is [[Sunni]]-based and says, "We use religion to unite, where others may seek to use it to divide". It is led by Waseem Razvi.
==Waseem Razvi==
The founding President of IREA, Waseem Razvi was born in 1981<ref name = saudi/> and brought up in [[Saudi Arabia]] by parents of Indian origin. In 2004, he moved to Australia for higher studies. He obtained a master's degree in information systems from the Melbourne Institute of Technology in 2007. He quit from his job in 2010 to engage fully in [[Dawah]] works.
Razvi has been quoted as describing Australia, "As the largest multicultural country in the world, Australia accommodates people from around 200 nationalities. It is an open migrant country that embraces people of all cultures and religions with open hands and hearts" and that "Australian society gives followers of different faiths every opportunity to propagate their religion peacefully." "I am delivering sermons in certain churches in which I try to present the true picture of Islam as well as to remove misgivings, with a focus on major similarities and commonalities of Islam and Christianity.”<ref name=saudi>{{cite news|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20130911179986 |title=Young preacher lauds Australia’s strength to embrace all faiths |author=Cheruppa, Hassan |date=11 September 2013 |work=[[Saudi Gazette]] |accessdate=21 April 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004063621/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20130911179986 |archivedate= 4 October 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Razvi has met with Egyptian Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] in [[Qatar]],<ref name = "CT1"/> who has said he supports IREA's dawah.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/newscustom/melbourne-islamic-conference-organiser-waseem-razvi-met-notorious-sheikh-20150325-1m7le9.html |title=Melbourne Islamic conference organiser Waseem Razvi met notorious sheikh |author=Bucci, Nino|date=25 March 2015|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
Razvi has travelled to [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Qatar]] to raise funds and to lecture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/in-depth/terror/school-funding-to-pay-for-radical-muslim-preachers/story-fnpdbcmu-1227074423698 |title=School funding to pay for radical Muslim preachers |author=Baxendale, Rachel|date=30 September 2014|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> He said in Saudi Arabia that there is a group in Australia, [[Q Society of Australia|Q Society]] , founded by Christian and Jewish zealots, with the slogan, 'Muslims should be kicked out of Australia.'<ref name = saudi/>
Razvi is a supporter of the late Islamic preacher, [[Ahmed Deedat]],<ref name = "Melbourne University"/><ref name = saudi/> whose books have been banned from sale in France for being, "violently anti-Western, anti-Semitic and inciting to racial hate."<ref name = "Melbourne University"/>
==The Australian Islamic Peace Conference==
IREA runs ''Australian Islamic Peace Conferences'' (AIPC) which the [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] has reported as a "controversial event".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/middle-east/hate-preachers-in-australia-uncovered-after-fiery-lateline-interview/story-fnh81ifq-1227086138502 |title=Hate preachers in Australia uncovered after fiery Lateline interview |date=10 October 2014|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]| accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
Razvi has described the three main goals of the ''Australian Islamic Peace Conferences'' was to, "achieving unity among Muslims, build bridges of understanding between Muslims and Australian community, and open a door of communications for Muslims with the authorities. Organization of AIPC was a culmination of my endeavors to achieve these goals and it was a very successful one."<ref name = saudi/>
The advertised main speaker for the 2013 Peace Conference was [[Abdul Rahman Al-Sudais]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/victoria/boy-5-to-headline-islamic-peace-conference/story-fnj4aog3-1227275803182 |title=Boy, 5, to headline Islamic ‘peace conference’ |date=24 March 2015|work=[[News Ltd]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref> who, "has called for violent jihad"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/fiery-imam-invited-to-speak-here-20121211-2b7td.html |title=Fiery imam invited to speak here |author=Zwartz, Barney|date=12 December 2012|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref> and is alleged to have made [[Antisemitic]] remarks.<ref name = "2013 conference">{{cite web|url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;db=CHAMBER;id=chamber%2Fhansards%2Faa257c64-8320-4cab-964d-8f041853ad36%2F0160;query=Id%3A%22chamber%2Fhansards%2Faa257c64-8320-4cab-964d-8f041853ad36%2F0000%22 |title=Australian Islamic Peace Conference |author=Senator Bernardi|date=12 March 2013|work=[[Australian Parliament House]]|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref> Prior to the conference Al-Sudais was denied a visa to enter Australia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/islam-forum-speakers-shrouded-in-secrecy/story-fn59niix-1227278760932 |title=Islam forum speakers shrouded in secrecy |author=Baxendale, Rachel|date=26 March 2015|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref> Speaking at the 2013 conference was [[Islamic Information and Services Network of Australasia|Abu Hamza]] who has been accused of telling men, "how to beat their wives".<ref name = "2013 conference"/>
For the 2013 Peace Conference, held at the [[Melbourne Showgrounds]], Christians from various churches initially had approval to hire a stall to give away Bibles. The approval was subsequently withdrawn. The explanation given was, "because it would be unsafe".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.menzieshouse.com.au?p=1360 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924180307/http://www.menzieshouse.com.au?p=1360 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 September 2015 |title=Not even true to themselves |author=Crocker, Geoff |date=16 March 2013|work=Menzies House|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref>
One of IREA's conferences was banned by the [[Melbourne University]] because it required gender segregation of the audience.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/higher-education/academic-calls-for-end-to-ritualised-humiliation/story-e6frgcjx-1226629597535 |title=Academic calls for end to 'ritualised humiliation' |author=Baxendale, Rachel|date=26 April 2013|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/melbourne-uni-cancels-inter-faith-event-by-islamic-research-and-educational-academy/story-e6frg6nf-1226640997698 |title=Melbourne Uni cancels 'inter-faith' event by Islamic Research and Educational Academy |author=Baxendale, Rachel|date=13 May 2013|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
At the 2015 conference, a young boy impersonated Islamic tele-evangelist [[Zakir Naik]] (Razvi's role model)<ref name = saudi/> who is banned in Britain<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/03/30/jews-were-behind-911-attack-says-msian-preacher/ |title=Jews were behind 9/11 attack, implies Malaysian preacher|date=30 March 2015|work=[[Free Malaysia Today]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref> and the conference keynote speaker [[Hussein Yee]] has implied that the Jews were behind the [[September 11 attacks|2001 World Trade Centre attack]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/islamic-conference-keynote-speaker-says-september-11-not-unjust/story-e6frg6nf-1227282382336 |title=Islamic conference keynote speaker says September 11 not unjust |author=Baxendale, Rachel|date=28 March 2015|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
The March 2017 conference is entitled, ''[[Quran]] The book that shook the world''. Speakers include [[Shady Alsuleiman]] and [[Keysar Trad]]. In the promotional flyers, the three females have their faces replaced with black ink, while the faces of all other 12 male speakers are displayed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/womens-faces-hidden-on-australian-islamic-peace-conference-flyer-sparking-outrage/news-story/565ef11479ce53341a1dc9b8fd17fbc6 |title=Women’s faces hidden on Australian Islamic Peace Conference flyer, sparking outrage |date=8 February 2017|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4201898/Islamic-Peace-Conference-hides-faces-women-flyer.html |title='It's backward and reduces them to faceless beings': Muslim conference under fire for deleting faces of female speakers on promotional flyer |author=Piotrowski, Daniel|date=8 February 2017|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> With organisers saying it was done to protect the women from being, "targeted in the streets."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/opinion/rita-panahi/bizarre-alliance-sees-regressive-left-tolerating-islamist-bigotry/news-story/5dcc28f70de23c0740633b55255673d5 |title=Bizarre alliance sees Regressive Left tolerating Islamist bigotry |author=[[Rita Panahi|Panahi, Rita]]|date=10 February 2017|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> Subsequently, one of the female speakers, Monique Toohey pulled out after seeing her face blacked out, saying, "I didn't feel like it aligned with my values, and certainly not in a way that I choose to represent myself publicly".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.3aw.com.au/news/islamic-conference-under-fire-for-a-flyer-which-doesnt-show-female-speakers-20170209-gu9gqz.html |title=Islamic Conference under fire for a flyer which doesn't show female speakers |date=9 February 2017|work=3AW|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4210590/Speaker-pulls-Melbourne-Islamic-Peace-conference.html |title='A roll my eyes moment': Female Muslim leader pulls out of Islamic conference - after organisers deleted women's faces from 'backwards' promotional flyer |author=Piotrowski, Daniel|date=10 February 2017|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref>
==Council for the Prevention of Islamophobia==
The ''Council for the Prevention of Islamophobia Inc'' is co-located with IREA. Razvi is the secretary of the organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://michaelsmithnews.typepad.com/.a/6a0177444b0c2e970d01b8d2733813970c-800wi |title=Association extract for Council for the Prevention of Islamophia |work=Consumer Affairs Victoria|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref> Its purpose is to, "to protect and defend the Muslim community from discrimination based on their Islamic faith and/or race by multiple means".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.consumer.vic.gov.au/clubs-and-not-for-profits/incorporated-associations/search-for-an-incorporated-association?id=9b60b348-46e6-e411-80ed-c4346bada684 |title=Council for the Prevention of Islamophobia |work=Consumer Affairs Victoria|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>
An Australian speaking tour by the Dutch-American activist and author [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], was proposed for April 2017. The ''Council for the Prevention of Islamophobia'' said there would be 5,000 protesters outside the [[Festival Hall (Melbourne)|Festival Hall]] in Melbourne if she was to speak at that venue,<ref name = "tour">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/ayaan-hirsi-ali-islam-critic-and-author-cancels-australian-tour/news-story/130e9e7659bcc8de20f4cb03fd6c164d |title=Islam critic Ayaan Hirsi Ali cancels tour |author=Maly, Paul|date=4 April 2017|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref> because, "she is an extremist who condones violence and radicalises people."<ref name = "CT1"/> Her Australian tour was cancelled.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/a/34888839/islam-critic-hirsi-ali-cancels-aust-tour |title=Islam critic Hirsi Ali cancels Aust tour |author=Tasker, Belinda|date=3 April 2017|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref><ref name = "tour"/>
==Mosque proposals==
Waseem Razvi and the IREA have been involved in proposals for [[Masjid|mosques]] in the Melbourne suburbs of [[Craigieburn, Victoria|Craigieburn]],<ref name="IREA">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/immigration/radicals-trip-in-race-to-put-out-the-begging-bowl/news-story/2c74e3ed3856c2ad9109e2a4d786b784 |title=Radicals trip in race to put out the begging bowl |author=Blaxendale, Rachel|date=16 July 2015|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> [[Melton, Victoria (suburb)|Melton]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/melton-protests-pro-and-antimuslim-groups-clash-20151122-gl531g.html |title=Melton protests: Pro and anti-Muslim groups clash |author=Webb, Carolyn|date=|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> and the [[City of Casey]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2016/04/05/19/31/residents-say-they-arent-racist-they-just-dont-want-new-mosque |title=Residents say they aren't racist, they just don't want new mosque|work=9News|date=5 April 2016|accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Biographies|date=September 2014}} {{self-published|date=September 2014}} }} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Jan Groenveld | image = Jan Groenveld.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth-date|1945}} | birth_place = Australia | death_date = {{Death date and given age |df=yes|2002|10|22 |57}} | death_place = [[Queensland, Australia]] | occupation = Founder,
'''Cult Awareness and Information Centre''' | spouse = Simon Groenveld | parents = | children = 7 }} '''Jan Groenveld''' (1945 – 22 October 2002) was a member of the [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS Church]] and the [[Jehovah's Witnesses]].{{cite web|last1=Groenveld|first1=Jan|title=About Jan|url=http://www.culthelp.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2&Itemid=3|website=Cult Awareness and Information Centre|accessdate=8 May 2015}}{{Self-published source|date=May 2015}} She spent fifteen years in these and other organisations before leaving them in 1975 and resolving to make more information about what she saw as "[[cult]]s" available to the general public.{{cite book|last1=Guilliatt|first1=Richard|title=Talk of the devil : repressed memory & the ritual abuse witch-hunt|date=1996|publisher=[[Text Publishing]]|location=Melbourne, Australia|isbn=9781875847297|url=http://www.culthelp.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1109&Itemid=17}} ==Freedom in Christ Ministry== Groenveld first began providing information about groups she referred to as cults to the public and counselling affected individuals in 1979. In 1980, she founded the ''Freedom in Christ'' [[Christian ministry|ministry]], whose purpose was to counsel former members of controversial groups, and provide information about coercive religious sects. Jan founded the Cult Awareness and Information Centre (CAIC), in 1990. Groenveld's CAIC website was started in 1991.{{cite web|last1=Groenveld|first1=Jan|title=Who on Earth is the Cult Awareness & Information Centre??|url=http://cac.ggcs.net.au/contributions.htm|publisher=Cult Awareness & Information Centre|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015033158/http://cac.ggcs.net.au/contributions.htm|archivedate=2009-10-15 }}{{Self-published source|date=May 2015}} Groenveld first met [[Steven Hassan]] in 1993, when she brought him to [[Brisbane, Australia]] from the United States for a seminar. Hassan educated Groenveld as to the "serious potential for doubt and lack of veracity in [[satanic ritual abuse]] stories". ==Cited as "cult expert"== In 1999 a [[Brisbane]] tabloid, the [[The Sunday Mail (Brisbane)|Sunday Mail]] interviewed Groenveld on the likelihood that more [[destructive cult]]s would show up in Australia during 1999 before the new Millennium. The publication titled Groenveld a "cult specialist"Griffith, C. (10 January 1999) "Doom Cults Aussie Alert", ''Sunday Mail'' [[Brisbane, Australia]], pages 1, 4.
However, Queensland cult specialist Jan Groenveld said the doomsday merchants were more likely to come to Australia. "If it's a biblical cult, they may go to Israel, but eastern, Nostradamus-based and UFO-based cults believe the southern hemisphere, in particular Australia, may suffer less or later damage as the end approaches." two other Australian publications, the [[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]], a Brisbane tabloid, and [[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] a tabloid in [[Hobart]] titled her a "cult expert."[http://www.culticstudiesreview.org/csr_news/csr_newsgrp/twelve_tribes_2002_02_31.htm Twelve Tribes Café in Australia], Griffith, Chris; Watt, Amanda (26 December 2001), ''Courier Mail'', Australia, page 7.
Brisbane cult expert Jan Groenveld said that the group's commercial operations may look benign, but that the public should be wary if approached by cult members with invitations to visit their community.Binet, Harriet (2 November 2000) "Cult Alert", ''[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]]'', (Australia), page 1.
A Brisbane cult expert Jan Groenveld has worked with the families of members involved with Infinity. She described it as a cult which used subtle mind control to manipulate people for financial gain. "They cut off their family if there is any opposition," Mrs Groenveld said. "People become separated from families and become totally absorbed. "They really get hooked on the leader. No one that's in a cult knows that it's a cult. "It's not until you start to see that things are wrong that you can see what you're in." Mrs Groenveld, who has counselled victims and families of cults for more than 20 years, said isolating people from their family and urging them to "stay away from unbelief" was a common tactic. She warned the publication about a cult called the [[Twelve Tribes Mission]], believing them to possess militant tendencies. She warned: ''"There are people out there all over the place who would like to be another Jim Jones"'', referring to the [[Peoples Temple]] suicides. Groenveld's work has also been cited in Snow's ''[[Deadly Cults|Deadly Cults: The Crimes of True Believers]]''.{{cite book | last = Snow | first = Robert L. | authorlink = | author2 = | title = [[Deadly Cults|Deadly Cults: The Crimes of True Believers]] | publisher = Praeger/Greenwood | year = 2003 | location = | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-275-98052-9 | page = 196}} ==Death== Jan Groenveld died in October 2002, and was survived by her husband, 3 sons, 2 daughters and 2 foster daughters.{{Cite web | title = In Memory of Jan Groenveld | author = Randy Watters | work = freeminds.org | date = 2002-11-02 | accessdate = 2015-05-08 | url = http://www.freeminds.org/jangroenveld.htm | language = | quote = }}{{Self-published source|date=May 2015}} ==See also== *[[Christian countercult movement]] *[[Anti-cult movement]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.culthelp.info/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1 Cult Awareness and Information Centre] Main page. {{Opposition_to_NRMs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Groenveld}} [[Category:Australian educators]] [[Category:Australian Pentecostals]] [[Category:Former Latter Day Saints]] [[Category:Exit counselors]] [[Category:Former Jehovah's Witnesses]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Critics of Mormonism]] [[Category:Critics of Jehovah's Witnesses]] [[Category:Critics of new religious movements]] [[Category:Former members of new religious movements]] [[Category:People of the Christian countercult movement]]

Its Lawyers Are on the Case | work =[[The Washington Post]] | page =C1, C5 | publisher =[[The Washington Post Company]] | date =August 19, 1995 }} | spouse = | children = | website = [http://www.scientology.org/news-media/biographies/weiland.html Kurt Weiland] at Scientology.org }} '''Kurt Weiland''' is a native of [[Austria]] and an executive in the [[Church of Scientology International]].{{cite news | last =Baker | first =Russ | title =Clash of Titans: The German Government says the Church of Scientology is a tyrannical cult that recalls the country's dark history. The Scientologists say it's the Germans who haven't changed. In an increasingly bitter battle, two powers collide over the meaning of freedom and the burden of the past | work =[[George (magazine)|George Magazine]] |date=April 1997}} He is director of external affairs for the [[Church of Scientology]]'s [[Office of Special Affairs]], and Scientology's vice president of communications. He is a member of the organization's [[board of directors]],{{cite news|title=Bush's Call to Church Groups To Get Untraditional Replies|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=February 20, 2001|last=Goodstein|first=Laurie|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0CEFD81F30F933A15751C0A9679C8B63|accessdate=2008-06-16}}{{cite news|title=Cruise's private Scientology sessions|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=January 31, 2002|last=Walls|first=Jeannette|author2=Ashley Pearson }} and handles government, legal and public affairs for [[Scientology]].{{cite news | last =Staff | title =Scientologists open office to fight bias | work =[[Chicago Tribune]] | page =7 | date =September 19, 2003 }} He has often represented Scientology to the press as a media spokesman.{{cite news | last =Russell | first =Ron | title =Brained: Mentally impaired Raul Lopez was $1.7 million richer as the result of an accident settlement -- until he joined the Church of Scientology | work =New Times Los Angeles | date =December 21, 2000 }} Weiland works out of the Church of Scientology's offices in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/091501/Worldandnation/_Mental_health__hotli.shtml|title='Mental health' hotline a blind lead: The televised blurb offered mental health assistance dealing with the attacks. Callers reached Scientologists|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=September 15, 2001|accessdate=2008-06-16|last=O'Neil|first=Deborah}}{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE1DC133FF934A25751C1A961958260 |title=National News Briefs; Scientologist's Death Could Lead to Charges|work=[[The New York Times]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=December 17, 1997|accessdate=2008-06-17|last=Staff}} ==Work for Church of Scientology== In 1984 Weiland was a member of the Church of Scientology's [[Religious Technology Center]], and performed work for the organization in [[Santa Barbara County, California|Santa Barbara]], [[California]].{{cite book | last =Atack | first =Jon | title =[[A Piece of Blue Sky|A Piece of Blue Sky: Scientology, Dianetics and L. Ron Hubbard Exposed]] | publisher =Carol Publishing Group | date =1990 | location =[[New York City|New York]] | pages =321 | isbn = 0-8184-0499-X}} Weiland was executive director of Scientology's Office of Special Affairs in 1994,{{cite news | last =Garcia | first =Wayne | title =Scientology publication criticizes the "Times' | work =[[St. Petersburg Times]] | page =3B | date =July 9, 1994 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/06/AR2005070601351.html|title=Scientology Fiction: The Church's War Against Its Critics -- and Truth|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]]|date=December 25, 1994|accessdate=2008-06-17|last=Leiby|first=Richard}} and was responsible for its international legal affairs and public relations.{{cite news | last =Garcia | first =Wayne | title =Network gives voice to former Scientologists | work =[[St. Petersburg Times]] | page =12A | date =August 3, 1994 }}{{cite news | last =Tobin | first =Thomas C. | title =Scientology looks into reporter's personal life | work =[[St. Petersburg Times]] | page =7A | date =March 27, 1998 }} In December 1994 he prevented Richard Leiby, a reporter for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', from attending a luncheon at the [[National Press Club (USA)|National Press Club]] sponsored by the Church of Scientology International.{{cite news | last =Tobin | first =Thomas C. | title =Scientology puts itself on display | work =[[St. Petersburg Times]] | page =1A, 4B | date =December 6, 1994 }} Weiland did not allow Leiby to enter the First Amendment Lounge, and told him: "You seem to make a living by writing falsehoods." "We know that you used to work in Clearwater, and we know exactly what you wrote," Weiland said to Leiby. In an interview at the National Press Club in 1994, the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' asked Weiland and Scientology President [[Heber Jentzsch]] about the Church of Scientology's practice of investigating reporters who write about Scientology. "First of all, we don't do that. There's no institutional or organized campaign or effort or action ongoing to go after a reporter," lied Weiland. When asked about a discrepancy after Church of Scientology officials confirmed in 1998 that their attorneys had hired a firm to investigate a reporter for the ''[[Boston Herald]]'', Weiland said: "It's not a personal thing. Every time a reporter steps out of his way to create damage to the church ... then, of course, it's gloves off." He said that the ''Boston Herald'' reporter's articles were inaccurate, and the Church of Scientology decided to investigate the individual in order to determine what "vested interest" he was working for and what "sinister motive" he had. Weiland was the Deputy Commanding Officer of the Office of Special Affairs in 1995,{{cite journal | last =Kent | first =Stephen A. | authorlink =Stephen A. Kent | title = Scientology and the European Human Rights Debate: A Reply to Leisa Goodman, J. Gordon Melton, and the European Rehabilitation Project Force Study | journal =Marburg Journal of Religion |publisher=[[University of Marburg]]| volume =8 | issue =1 | date =September 2003 | url =http://web.uni-marburg.de/religionswissenschaft/journal/mjr/kent3.html | accessdate =2008-06-16}} and served on the board of directors of the Church of Scientology International.{{cite news|title=Rights to rites Scientologists defend actions against critic|work=[[Denver Post]]|date=August 30, 1995|page=B-01|last=Hodges|first=Arthur}}{{cite news | last =Fisher | first =Marc ([[The Washington Post]]) | title =Critics bedevil Scientology - Secretive organization launches a strike to protect sacred texts | work =[[The Kansas City Star]] | page =A1 | date =August 20, 1995 }} In 1996 he was director of the Office of Special Affairs,{{cite news | last =Wallsten | first =Peter | title =Scientologists don't take protest quietly | work =[[St. Petersburg Times]] | page =1B, 4B | date =March 10, 1996 }} and in 1997 Weiland managed external affairs for the Church of Scientology.{{cite news | last =Sharpe | first =Tom | title =NY Times Details Church's Tax Battle | work =[[Albuquerque Journal]] | date =March 13, 1997 }}{{cite news | last =Ribadeneira | first =Diego | title =Gifts of Cash Fuel Battle of Principle Hub Man's Aid to Scientology Critics Draws Fire and Rhetoric From Church | work =[[Boston Globe]] | page =B1 | date =December 9, 1997 }} On June 13, 2003, Weiland accompanied actor and Scientologist [[Tom Cruise]] and director of the Church of Scientology's [[Los Angeles]] [[Celebrity Centre]], [[Thomas W. Davis|Tommy Davis]], to meet with then-[[United States]] [[Deputy Secretary of State]] [[Richard Armitage (politician)|Richard Armitage]].{{cite book|last =Morton| first =Andrew| authorlink =Andrew Morton (writer)| title =[[Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography]]| publisher =[[St. Martin's Press]]| date =2008| location =[[New York City|New York]] | pages =242–243| isbn =0-312-35986-1 |quote=On June 13, 2003, one of the most powerful men in America, Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage, met privately with Tom Cruise, together with his friend Tom Davis, head of the Hollywood Celebrity Centre, and Kurt Weiland, an Austrian Scientologist who was director of external affairs for the organization's Office of Special Affairs. For thirty minutes Armitage listened as they expressed their concerns about the treatment of Scientologists in some foreign countries, particularly Germany.}}{{cite news | last =Staff | title =Tom 'Incensed' Sumner's Wife | work =[[New York Post]] | page =14 | publisher =N.Y.P. Holdings, Inc. | date =August 25, 2006 }}{{cite news | last =Derakhshani | first =Tirdad | title =Cruise camp: sorry about Shields | work =[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] | date =August 26, 2006 }} In the half-hour-long private meeting, they raised concerns with Armitage about the treatment of Scientologists in [[Germany]] and other countries. In 2006, Weiland was listed on a "Senior Honor Roll" in ''Impact'', the magazine of the [[International Association of Scientologists]].{{cite journal | last =[[International Association of Scientologists]] | title =Senior Honor Roll | journal =Impact | issue=114 | date =2006 }} ==See also== {{Portal|Scientology}} * [[List of Scientologists]] * [[Office of Special Affairs]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite news | last =[[International Association of Scientologists]] | title =Mr. Kurt Weiland: Deputy Commanding Officer, Office of Special Affairs International | work =Impact| pages =10–13 | publisher =[[Church of Scientology]] | date =1995 }} ([http://web.uni-marburg.de/religionswissenschaft/journal/mjr/kent3.html excerpted in ''Marburg Journal of Religion'']) ==External links== * {{cite web|url=http://www.scientology.org/news-media/biographies/weiland.html |title=Kurt Weiland - Director, Church of Scientology International|work=Scientology - Church of Scientology Official Site|publisher=www.scientology.org|last=[[Church of Scientology International]]}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.scientology.org/scnnews/weiland.htm|title=Kurt Weiland: External Affairs Director|work=Scientology in the News: Press Office|publisher=www.scientology.org|last=[[Church of Scientology International]]}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.scientology.org/humanrights/news/030303.htm|title=Church of Scientology International Opens European Office In Brussels|work=Human Rights News - ==Hadith collections== {{Hadith}}
===[[The Four Books|Al-Kutub al-Arbaʿah]]=== * [[Kitab al-Kafi]] by [[Kulayni]] (864 AD - 941 AD) ''(divided into Usul al-Kafi, Furu al-Kafi and Rawdat al-Kafi)'' * [[Man la Yahdhuruhu'l Faqih]] by [[Al-Shaykh-Al-Saduq|Shaykh Saduq]] (923 AD - 991 AD) * [[Tahdhib al-Ahkam]] by [[Abu Ja'far al-Tusi]] (995 AD - 1067 AD) * [[Al-Istibsar]] by [[Abu Ja'far al-Tusi]] (995 AD - 1067 AD)
===[[Other Major Hadith collections]]=== * [[The Book of Sulaym ibn Qays]] by [[Sulaym ibn Qays]] ( ?? - 695 AD) * [[Daim al-Islam]] by [[Al-Qadi al-Nu'man]] ''([[Isma'ilism|Isma'ili Shia]])'' ( ?? - 974 AD) * [[Al-Ihtijaj (book)|Al-Ihtijaj]] by [[Abu Mansur Ahmad Tibrisi]] * [[Wasā'il al-Shīʿa]] by [[Shaikh al-Hur al-Aamili]] (1624 AD to 1693 AD) * [[Bihar al-Anwar]] by [[Allama Majlesi]] (1627 AD to 1699 AD) * [[Reality of Certainty|Haq ul-Yaqeen]] by [[Allama Majlisi]] (1627 AD to 1699 AD) * [[Essence of Life (book)|Ayn al-Hayat]] by [[Allama Majlisi]] (1627 AD to 1699 AD) * [http://wilayatmission.org/kamil-al-ziarat-english-translation/ Kamil al Ziarat]<ref>http://wilayatmission.org/kamil-al-ziarat-english-translation/</ref> by [[ibn al-Qummi]] ''(collection of hadiths and ziarats (sacred visits) regarding the visitation of the Imams (as) and Karbala)''
===Hadith`s Anthologies & Commentaries=== * [[Shahr Usul al-Kafi]] — by [[Mohammad Salih al-Mazandarani]] * [[A Bundle of Flowers]] — collected by [[Ayatollah]] [[Sayyid Kamal Faghih Imani]]; ''a popular English language secondary collection of Shi'a hadith. It narrates traditions from such Shia collections as [[Kitab al-Kafi]] and [[Man la Yahdhuruhu'l Faqih]].'' * [[A Shi'ah Anthology]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.al-islam.org/publishers/mtrust/antholgy.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20011109005952/http://www.al-islam.org/publishers/mtrust/antholgy.htm |archivedate=2001-11-09 |df= }}</ref> — by [[William Chittick]], [[Hossein Nasr]] and [[Muhammad Husayn Tabataba'i]]; ''a brief introduction to exemplary hadith from the 12 Imams.''
==Theology of Shi'a== These books include discussions about Theology ([[Tawḥīd]], [[Nubuwwah]], [[Imamate|Imamah]], etc. ) of Shi'a.
===Classic Kalam=== These books seek to give a rational account of Shi'a theology in contrast with the [[Ash'ari]], [[Mu'tazili]] and other [[Muslim theology|theological schools of Islam]]. The contents of these books are taken from the 8th to the 13th century (2nd to 7th century of Islam). * [[Eʿteqādātal-Emāmīya]] by [[Shaykh Saduq]] (923 AD - 991 AD) * [[Al-Amali (of Shaykh Mufid)|Al-Amali]] by [[Sheikh al-Mufid]] (948 AD to 1022 AD) * [[Tashih al-I'tiqad]] by [[Shaykh Mufid]] (948 AD - 1022 AD), ''a correction of [[Shaykh Saduq]]'s [[Eʿteqādātal-Emāmīya]].'' * [[Tajrid al-i‘tiqad]] by [[Nasir al-Din Tusi]] (1201 AD - 1274 AD)
===Modern Kalam=== These books seek to give a rational account of Shi'a theology in contrast with modern Western ideologies including [[Marxism]] and [[Liberalism]] during the 20th century. * [[Fundamentals Of Islamic Thought]] by [[Morteza Motahhari]], ''trans. R. Campbell: Berkeley, California, Mizan Press, 1982.''

==History books== *[[Kamaaluddin wa Tamamum ul Ne'amah]]— by [[Shaikh Saduq]] (923 AD - 991 AD) *[[Tazkar-tul-Athar]]— by [[Sheikh al-Mufid]] (948 AD - 1022 AD) *[[Majalis al-muminin]]— by [[Qazi Nurullah Shustari]] ( (1542 AD - 1610 AD) *[[A 250 Years Old Person]]— by [[Ali Khamenei]] (1939 AD - Present)

It contains [[monolith]]s *quarried, but not moved *quarried and moved *quarried, moved and lifted clear off the ground into their position ([[architrave]]s etc.) *quarried, moved and erected in an upright position ([[column]]s etc.) Transporting was done by land or water (or a combination of both), in the later case often by special-built ships such as [[obelisk carrier]]s.{{harnvb|Wirsching|2000}} For lifting operations, [[Crane (machine)#History|ancient cranes]] were employed since ca. 515 BC, such as in the [[Trajan's Column#Erection|construction of Trajan's Column]].{{harvnb|Lancaster|1999|pp=419–439}} It should be stressed that all numbers are estimations since only in the rarest cases have monoliths been actually weighed. Rather, weight is calculated by multiplying [[volume]] by [[density]]. The main source, J. J. Coulton, assumes 2.75 t/m³ for [[marble]] and 2.25 t/m³ for other stone.{{harnvb|Coulton|1974|p=14}} For an explanation of the large margin of error, which often leads to widely differing numbers, see [[List of megalithic sites#Calculating the weight of megaliths|these introductory remarks]]. == Greek monoliths == Below a selection of Greek monoliths sorted by their date. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:1px; border:1px solid #cccccc; " |----- align="left" valign="top" bgcolor="cccccc" ! width="10%" | Date ! width="20%" | Building / Object ! width="20%" | Location ! width="20%" | Monolith ! width="10%" | Weight

page.title: List of converts to Christianity from paganism

revision.text:
This is a '''list of notable converts to Christianity from pagan religions'''. [[Paganism]] is a term which, from a [[Western world|Western]] perspective, has come to connote a broad set of [[spiritualism|spiritual]] or [[ritual|cultic]] practices or beliefs of any [[folk religion]], and of historical and contemporary [[polytheism|polytheistic]] religions in particular.
While the term has historically been used to denote adherents of any non-[[Abrahamic faith]], for the purposes of this list, only adherents of non-major [[polytheism|polytheistic]], [[shamanism|shamanistic]], [[pantheism|pantheistic]], or [[animism|animistic]] religions will be listed in this section.
==British Isles/Celtic/Germanic (excluding Norse) paganism== * [[Aebbe the Elder]] - Scottish monastic founder.<ref>[http://www.olotrosarypeterlee.co.uk/Northernsaints.html The Northern Saints<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070927034343/http://www.olotrosarypeterlee.co.uk/Northernsaints.html |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> * [[Saint Alban]] - first Christian martyr in Britain.<ref>[http://www.catholic-forum.com/saints/sainta34.htm Patron Saints Index: Saint Alban<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120910231101/http://www.catholic-forum.com/saints/sainta34.htm |date=2012-09-10 }}</ref> * [[Cenwalh of Wessex]] - [[King of Wessex]].<ref>Bede, ''Ecclesiastical History of the English People'', Book III, chapter 7.</ref> * [[Constantine of Cornwall]] - 6th-century king of Dumnonia.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} * [[Saint Constantine of Strathclyde]] - King of [[Strathclyde]], and later abbot of [[Rahan, County Offaly|Rahan]].<ref>[http://www.britannia.com/bios/ebk/constsc.html Britannia EBK Biographies: St. Constantine, King of Strathclyde<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Óengus mac Nad Froích]] - 5th century [[King of Munster]] * [[Cynegils]] - [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] king of the [[West Saxons]].<ref>[http://www.berkshirehistory.com/bios/cynegils.html Berkshire History: Biographies: St. Abban of Abingdon<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Raedwald of East Anglia]] - [[King of East Anglia]] from about AD 599 to about AD 625.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9062445/Raedwald Raedwald - Britannica Online Encyclopedia<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Sigeberht of East Anglia]] - [[King of East Anglia]] from AD 631 to 634.<ref>D.H. Farmer, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Saints'' (Oxford 1978). {{ISBN|0-19-282038-9}}.</ref> * [[Riderch I of Alt Clut|Riderch Hael]] - King of [[Strathclyde]] who established the first See of Strathclyde at [[Glasgow]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mun.ca/mst/heroicage/issues/2/ha2rh.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831210511/http://www.mun.ca/mst/heroicage/issues/2/ha2rh.htm |archivedate=2009-08-31 |df= }}</ref> * [[Æthelberht of Kent]] - [[Kings of Kent|King]] of [[Kingdom of Kent|Kent]].<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05553b.htm CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: St. Ethelbert (King of Kent)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Clovis I]] - early king of the Franks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://concise.britannica.com/ebc/article-9024458/Clovis-I |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017050359/http://concise.britannica.com/ebc/article-9024458/Clovis-I |archivedate=2007-10-17 |df= }}</ref> *[[Igraine]] - mother of [[King Arthur]] * [[Peada of Mercia]] - King of southern [[Mercia]]; helped found the [[monastery]] at [[Peterborough]].<ref>[http://www.gutenberg.org/files/16790/16790-8.txt Allen, Grant. ''"Anglo-Saxon Britain"''.]</ref> * [[Leonard of Noblac]] - Frankish noble in the court of [[Clovis I]].<ref>[http://www.catholic-forum.com/saints/saintl09.htm Patron Saints Index: Saint Leonard of Noblac<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120813044926/http://www.catholic-forum.com/saints/saintl09.htm |date=2012-08-13 }}</ref> * [[Edwin of Northumbria]] - King of Deira and Bernicia.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} * [[Rumwold of Buckingham|Rumwold]] - legendary "infant saint".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060518102135/http://www.catholic-forum.com/SAINTS/saintr28.htm]</ref> * [[Saint Bavo]] - Frankish eremitic monk who lived during the [[Middle Ages]].<ref>[http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=555 St. Bavo - Catholic Online<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Norse paganism==
* [[Leif Ericson]] - [[Iceland]]ic [[Viking]] explorer.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/erikson_leif.shtml BBC - History - Leif Erikson (11th century)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Guthrum of East Anglia]] - King of the Danish Vikings in the [[Danelaw]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=iJIBAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=%22guthrum+of+east+anglia%22+christian&source=web&ots=IYMKaWf-ch&sig=5hplEwTzH3mqD9fAv61YF9tPw50 Green, John Richard. ''"A short history of the English people"''.]</ref> * [[Rollo of Normandy]] - founder of Viking province of [[Normandy]].<ref>[http://sbaldw.home.mindspring.com/hproject/prov/rollo000.htm Rollo of Normandy<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Saint Olaf]] - King of Norway.<ref>[http://www.viking.no/e/people/st.olav/index.html Olav Haraldsson<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Rorik of Dorestad]] - Danish Viking leader.<ref>[http://www.missgien.net/vikings/rorik.html Viking in the Netherlands<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Graeco-Roman Paganism== * [[Saint Apollonius]] - 2nd-century Roman Senator, Christian apologist and martyr.<ref>[http://www.saintpatrickdc.org/ss/0418.shtml Saint Patrick's Church: Saints of April 18<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Coelia Concordia]] - last Roman [[Vestal Virgin]].<ref>[http://www.ancientworlds.net/aw/Article/634992 Forum Romanum: the Temple of Vesta and the Vestal Virgins<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051219064338/http://www.ancientworlds.net/aw/Article/634992 |date=2005-12-19 }}</ref> * [[Commodianus]] - Latin poet; first practiced Judaism, and later converted to Christianity.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04165a.htm CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Commodianus<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Constantine I]] (the Great) - [[Roman Emperor]] who legalized Christianity in the [[Edict of Milan]] in 313.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04295c.htm CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Constantine the Great<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Pertinax of Byzantium]] - Bishop of Byzantium from 169 until his death in 187.<ref>[http://www.ec-patr.eu/list/index.php?lang=en&id=15 Ecumenical Patriarchate<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Athenagoras of Athens]] - philosopher and early Christian apologist.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02042b.htm CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Athenagoras<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Dionysius the Pseudo-Areopagite]] - judge of the [[Areopagus]] and early Bishop of [[Athens]].<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05013a.htm CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Dionysius the Pseudo-Areopagite<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Saint Eustace]] - {{More footnotes|date=April 2013}} '''Mbwiri''' is a [[Central Africa]]n [[demon]] who is said to possess people. Those he possesses would usually be diagnosed with [[epilepsy]] by a doctor.
When such a possession occurs, the [[shaman]] is called. A hut is built in which the afflicted resides along with the shaman and his assistants until he is cured. For ten days or a fortnight these people eat and drink at the expense of the patient's relatives, and dance to the music of flute and drum. Mbwiri is said to abhor good living, and this is the best way to drive him out. The patient will be the only one who knows that he is possessed. The patient also dances until the epileptic fits come on. When he is pronounced cured, he builds a little [[Fetishism|fetish]] house, and thenceforth avoids certain kinds of food and performs certain duties. Sometimes, however, the process appears to result in madness, and some patients run away into the bush.
==References== *Lewis Spence, An Encyclopedia of Occultism, Routledge, London, 1988

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} '''Nicky Imber''' ([[Vienna]] 1920 -1996) was a multidisciplinary Jewish artist best known for his sculptures on Jewish themes. Grand nephew of [[Naftali Herz Imber]], author of the Israeli national anthem '[[Hatikva]]'. [[File:Nicky Imber working on head.jpg|thumb|250px|Nicky Imber working on sculpture]] After escaping the Nazi concentration camp in [[Dachau]],The Daily Journal Friday September 22, 1972 he pledged to dedicate his art to perpetuating the memory of the Holocaust. Among his more famous works are "[[The Hope (Imber)|The Hope]]" and "The Love of Torah". His work can be seen around the world, in [[Northern Israel]], the [[United States]], and the Venezuelan Museum of Natural History in Caracas. == Biography== Nicky Imber was born in [[Vienna]], Austria. During his studies at the Academy of Arts in Vienna, he drew anti-Nazi caricatures for Jewish student publications.Meir Hareuveni, Ma'ariv newspaper, September 22, 1981 After several thwarted attempts by the family to leave Vienna, in 1938, in the wake of the '[[Anschluss]]', Imber was deported to [[Dachau]]. Witnessing the murders of family and friends, he plotted his escape. Using skills he had learned in art school, he made a face mask out of bread and sand, stole a Nazi soldier's uniform and walked out the front gate unnoticed.Letter from [[Carmiel]],1981 Yad Vashem Archives In 1940, he boarded a ship headed to [[Haifa]]. The ship's passengers were refused entry by the British mandatory authorities and imprisoned in a detention camp in [[Mauritius]]. In 1943, Imber worked out a deal with the authorities for his release by joining the British Army, serving as a war artist and a dental assistant in East Africa. After the war, he opened an art school in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]], and worked as a photographer and a safari guide. In 1949 to 1954, he lived in [[Venezuela]], where he was contracted to do an East African [[Diorama]] series. The National Museum added an entire wing to display it.Ve Venezuela Vol.2 No.56 April–May 1975
During this period he got married and had a daughter Raquel, who accompanied and assisted him. [[File:Nicky Imber with one of the sculptures of the prehistoric animals.jpg|thumb|Nicky Imber with one of his prehistoric animal sculptures]] In 1959, Imber was commissioned to create sculptures and dioramas for the Haifa Prehistory Museum at Gan Ha-em in [[Haifa]], Israel. In 1960 he returned to Venezuela to restaured the Phelps series of Dioramas for the Museum in Caracas.Münstersche Zeitung Friday August 22, 1980 Between 1961 and 1971 he travelled extensively around Europe and after establishing an international name for himself, returned to the United States. In New York he became famous for his realistic oil paintings of portraits of [[Aga Khan]], [[Tyrone Power]], [[Ava Gardner]], [[David Ben-Gurion]], [[Golda Meir]], [[Sir Richard Burton]] and [[Simon Bolivar]].The Sun Reporter Tuesday July 31, 1973 Returning to Venezuela in 1976, Imber created huge sculptures of prehistoric animals, forming one of the world's largest historical animal parks. During this period he also created realistic sculptures of famous Venezuelans for the country's National Hall of Fame.El Nacional, Caracas, Thursday, April 22, 1976
In 1978, Imber spent three years designing and building a Holocaust memorial park at the entrance to the city of [[Karmiel]] located in the Galilee, entitled 'From Holocaust to Resurrection.' Imber also established animal theme playgrounds around the city. [[File:Nicky Imber building "Hope" in Carmiel, Israel.JPG|thumb|Nicky Imber building "Hope" in Carmiel, Israel]] In the 1980s, Imber established residence in Karmiel, Israel. In Israel he was inspired to create highly emotional, life like collections. Nicky Imber died in 1996 in Vienna, Austria. ==See also== *[[Visual arts in Israel]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{official website|http://nicky-imber.com/}} * Diana Lerner, Imberman dream of "City of Dreams", Ma'ariv, December 24, 1959 {{DEFAULTSORT:Imber, Nicky}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:Artists from Vienna]] [[Category:Jewish artists]] [[Category:Dachau concentration camp survivors]]

[[Arie Belldegrun]] (brother-in-law) |known_for = [[Private collection|Art collection]], [[philanthropy]] |signature = |signature_alt= |website = }} '''Chaim''' "'''Poju'''" '''Zabludowicz''' (born 6 April 1953) is a [[Finnish people|Finnish]]-born [[British people|British]] [[business magnate]], investor, art collector and philanthropist.[http://www.zabludowiczcollection.com/collection/people "People"], ''Zabludowicz Collection''. Retrieved on 26 June 2013.Midgley, Dominic (5 March 2010). [http://business.highbeam.com/5729/article-1G1-220443643/finn-city-he-friends-madonna-has-vast-collection-modern "FINN CITY..."]. ''Highbeam Business'' (London). Retrieved 23 June 2013.{{cite news |title=Finnish-born tycoon Poju Zabludowicz met President Niinistö during Olympics visit |first= |last= |url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Finnish-born+tycoon+Poju+Zabludowicz+met+President+Niinist%C3%B6+during+Olympics+visit/1329104537911 |newspaper=Helsingin Sanomat |location=Helsinki |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=26 June 2013 }} The ''[[Sunday Times Rich List 2018]]'' of the wealthiest people in the United Kingdom ranked him 90th with a personal net worth of [[Pound sterling|£]]1,500 million.Rea, Naomi (15 May 2018). [https://news.artnet.com/art-world/art-world-2018-sunday-times-rich-list-1286075 "11 Art World Players Who Made the 2018 Sunday Times ‘Rich List’"]. ''Artnet''. Retrieved 15 May 2018. ==Early life== Zabludowicz was born in [[Helsinki]], the son of arms industry businessman [[Shlomo Zabludowicz]],{{cite news |last=Miettinen |first=Anssi |date=September 2011 |title=Isänsä poika |url= |newspaper=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] Kuukausiliite |pages=25–33 }} and raised in [[Tampere]], where he attended ''Svenska Samskolan i Tammerfors'', the Swedish-speaking school in the city. He graduated with a degree in Economics and Political Science from [[Tel Aviv University]] and later worked at BFG Bank AG in [[Frankfurt]].[http://www.thejlc.org/author/pzabludowicz/ "Poju Zabludowicz"], ''The Jewish Leadership Council''. Retrieved on 26 June 2013. He is married to UK-born [[Anita Zabludowicz]].Jury, Louise (18 September 2007). [https://www.standard.co.uk/arts/billionaires-wife-gives-young-artists-a-chance-6648079.html "Billionaire's wife gives young artists a chance"]. ''The Evening Standard'' (London). Retrieved 26 June 2013. His father, Shlomo, built the family business around [[Soltam]], an Israeli [[defence contractor]].Korin-Lieber, Stella (4 February 2013). [http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000819435&fid=1725 "Pujo Zabludowicz mulls raising stake in El Al parent"]. ''Globes''. Retrieved 26 June 2013. ==Career ventures== In 1978, Zabludowicz was appointed a [[Board of directors|Director]] of Tamares, the family's [[holding company]], and has headed the company since 1990. Tamares invests in a number of different private[http://www.tamares.com/portfolio/selected-investments-private "Selected Investments (Private)"], ''Tamares''. Retrieved on 26 June 2013. and public[http://www.tamares.com/portfolio/selected-investments-listed "Selected Investments (Listed)"], ''Tamares''. Retrieved on 26 June 2013. companies, and in real estate properties.[http://www.tamares.com/portfolio/selected-properties "Selected Properties"], ''Tamares''. Retrieved on 26 June 2013. The company owns 40% of the land in downtown Las Vegas.[http://www.egi.co.uk/news/article.aspx?id=662493 "EG Rich List 2007 Nos 1–14"]. ''Estates Gazette''. 27 November 2007. Retrieved 26 June 2013. Today, Tamares Group holds a $3 billion portfolio. Its real estate holdings encompass 2.3 million square feet of office space.[https://www.tamares.com/ "Tamares"]. ''Tamares''. Retrieved 29 May 2017. In 1993, Zabludowicz set up Ivory Gate, a [[real estate investing|property investment]] company based in London. Using offshore vehicles, Ivory Gate made investments in UK commercial property. In 2006, Zabludowicz established and was the chairman of the Advisory Board of Auctor Capital Partners, a corporate finance and advisory house for hedge funds. {{Italics title|string=Pratima}} {{Jainism}} In [[Jainism]], '''''Pratima''''' ({{lang-sa|प्रतिमा}}) is a step or a stage marking the spiritual rise of a [[Śrāvaka (Jainism)|lay person]] (''shravak''). There are eleven such steps called ''pratima''.Shravakachar Sangrah, Five Volumes, Hiralal Jain Shastri, Jain Sanskruti Samrakshak Sangh Solapur, 1988 After having passed the eleven steps, one is no longer a ''sravaka'', but a ''muni'' ([[Jain monasticism|monk]]). Rules prescribed for laymen are divided into twelve ''vrata'' (vows) and eleven ''pratimas'' (steps){{sfn|Champat Rai Jain|1917|p=77}} and are described in several codes of conduct ([[Ratnakaranda|''shravakacharas'']]).Jaina yoga: a survey of the mediaeval śrāvakācāras By R. Williams The ''pratimas'' are mentioned in several ancient texts like [[Ratnakaranda Shravakachara]] (2nd century A.D.).Upasakdashang aur uska Shravakachar, Subhash Kothari, Agam Ahimsa Samta Evam Prakrit Sansthan, Udaipur 1988 == Twelve vows == The twelve vows are: {|class="wikitable" |- ! Head ! Vow ! Meaning |- style="background:#FFF;" |rowspan="5"|'''Five vows'''
|1. [[Ahimsa in Jainism|ahiṃsā]] | Not to hurt any living being by actions and thoughts |- style="background:#FFF;" |2. [[satya]] | Not to lie or speak what is not commendable.{{sfn|Vijay K. Jain|2012|p=61}} |- style="background:#FFF;" |3. [[asteya]] | Not to take anything if not given.{{sfn|Vijay K. Jain|2012|p=68}} |- style="background:#FFF;" |4. [[brahmacharya]] | Chastity / Celibacy in action, words and thoughts |- style="background:#FFF;" |5. [[Aparigraha]] ([[Non-possession]]) | Detachment from material property. |- style="background:#ADFF2F;" |rowspan="3"|'''Guņa vratas'''{{sfn|Vijay K. Jain|2012|p=88}}
|6. ''digvrata'' | Restriction on movement with regard to directions. |- style="background:#ADFF2F;" |7. ''bhogopabhogaparimana'' | Vow of limiting consumable and non-consumable things |- style="background:#ADFF2F;" |8. ''anartha-dandaviramana'' | Refraining from harmful occupations and activities (purposeless sins). |- style="background:#FF0;" |rowspan="4"|'''Śikşā vratas'''{{sfn|Tukol|1976|p=5}}{{sfn|Vijay K. Jain|2012|p=88}}
|9. ''[[Sāmāyika|samayika]]'' | Vow to meditate and concentrate periodically. |- style="background:#FF0;" |10. ''desavrata'' | Limiting movement to certain places for a fixed period of time.{{sfn|Vijay K. Jain|2012|p=90}} |- style="background:#FF0;" |11. ''upvas'' | Fasting at regular intervals. |- style="background:#FF0;" |12. ''atihti samvibhag'' | Vow of offering food to the ascetic and needy people |} == Eleven ''Pratima'' == The eleven stages (''pratima'') are:{{sfn|Champat Rai Jain|1917|p=83}} #Darshan Pratima (Right perspective): The worship of the true God (i.e., tirthanhara,) guru (preceptor) and shastra (Scripture), and the avoidance of gambling, meat-eating, drinking (wine), adultery, hunting, thieving and debauchery. #Vrat Pratima: The keeping of the twelve vows and the vow to observe [[sallekhana]] (at the end of one's life) #Samayak Pratima (Periodic meditation): Engaging in meditation or worship on a regular basis. #Proshadhopvas Pratima (periodic fasting): fasting four times in a month. #Sachitta Tyaga Pratima: not eating vegetables having the capacity to grow again. #Ratribhukti Tyaga Pratima (or Diva Maithun Tyaga Pratima): Giving up eating during the night or coitus during the day. #Brahmacharya Pratima (celibacy): abstaining from sex or related activity. #Arambha Tyaga Pratima (giving up occupations): refraining from any activity to earn a living. #Parigraha Tyaga Pratima (giving up possessions): detachment from most possessions. #Anurnati Tyaga Pratima (giving up right to give permissions): refraining from giving orders or expressing consents in the family. #Uddishta Tyaga Pratima: The complete renunciation of the householder’s life, retiring into a forest and adopting the rules laid down for the guidance of monks.{{sfn|Champat Rai Jain|1917|p=84}} Ashadhara in his Sagara-Dharmammrata (13th century) has groups the 11 steps into three ranks. *Grahin (jaghanya: first to sixth pratima) *Varnin (madhyama: seventh to ninth pratima): At this point the householder is termed a [[Varni]]. The pratimas are: *Bhikshuka (uttama: tenth and eleventh pratima): At this point a person depends on others for daily survival. Those who have ascended to the eleventh pratima are termed [[Kshullaka]] (with two articles of clothing) and [[Jain Muni|Ailaka]] (with only one piece of cloth) in the [[Digambara]] tradition. The eleventh pratima is termed Shramanabhuta Pratima (being almost like a Shramana) in the [[Svetambara]] tradition. The next step is that of a full [[Jain muni|Jain Muni]]. ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} === Sources === *{{Citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EscwAQAAMAAJ|title=The Practical Path|author1=Jain|first1=Champat Rai|authorlink=Champat Rai Jain|year=1917|publisher=The Central Jaina Publishing House}} * {{citation |last=Jain |first=Vijay K. |authorlink=Vijay K. {{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{other uses|Protector (disambiguation)}} '''Protector''', sometimes spelled '''protecter''', is used as a title or part of various historical titles of heads of state and others in authority. The word literally means ''one who protects''.
==Political and administrative==
===Heads of state===
====Iran==== ''Wakil ar-Ra`aya'' (rendered as '''Protector of the People''') was the (or a?) title of the Persian imperial Monarch under the [[Zand dynasty|Zand]] dynasty - those rulers refused (except the last as noted) the style [[Shahanshah]]. The founding ruler adopted the style; it appears that his successors used the same style, although documentation is obscure *1773 - 1 March 1779 Mohammad Karim Khan Zand (b. c.1707 - d. 1779) *6 March 1779 - 1779 Abu al-Fath Khan Zand (1st time) (b. 1755 - d. 1787) - ''jointly with'' 6 March 1779 - 19 June 1779 Mohammad Ali Khan Zand (b. 1760 - d. 1...) *19 June 1779 - 22 August 1779 Abu al-Fath Khan Zand (2nd time) *22 August 1779 - 14 March 1781 Mohammad Sadeq Khan Zand (d. 1782) *15 March 1781 - 11 February 1785 Ali Morad Khan Zand (d. 1785) *12 February 1785 - 17 February 1785 Baqer Khan Khorasakani *18 February 1785 - 23 January 1789 Jaafar Khan Zand (d. 1789) *23 January 1789 - 10 May 1789 Seyd Morad Khan Zand *10 May 1789 - 30 October 1794 Lotf Ali Khan Zand (b. c.1766 - d. 1794); he again adopted the traditional style [[Shah]]anshah March 1794 - 30 October 1794
====Europe==== : ''for the use in the British Isles as regent during minority or incapacity of the King and as republican Head of state of the Cromwellian Commonwealth see [[Lord Protector]]'' *[[Iceland]]: one Sovereign was styled ''Alls Íslands '''Verndari''' og Hæstráðandi til Sjós og Lands'' ("Protector and supreme authority of all of Iceland on land and sea") 25 June - 22 August 1809 (an intermezzo between Danish Governors styled ''[[Stiftamtmadur]])'': [[Jürgen Jürgensen]] (b. 1780 - d. 1841; nicknamed ''Hundadagakonungur'' "the Dog-Day King") . *[[Estonia]]: ''State-protector'' is a common rendering of [[Riigihoidja]], a single Head of state and Head of government of that Baltic republic, 24 January 1934 - 24 April 1938 (acting to 3 September 1937), Konstantin Päts (b. 1874 - d. 1956), earlier five times State Elder, thereafter the first and only President before the Soviet takeover. *[[Finland]] (linguistically close to Estonian): State Protector is a common rendering, besides Regent, of two Finnish Heads of State 18 May 1918 - 27 July 1919, the first incumbent being also the last of the previous -untitled- Acting heads of state *The elective kingdom called 'Commonwealth' of Poland & Lithuania, August 1655 – 23 February 1660: King [[Karl X Gustaf]] (b. 1622 - d. 1660) (as King of Sweden), in Polish Karol X Gustaw, was styled '''''Protektor''' Rzeczypospolitej'' ('Protector of the Republic, i.e. the (Polish-Lithuanian) Commonwealth') as challenger to the duly elected king Jan II Kazimierz during the middle part of his reign (17 January 1649 - 16 September 1668)
====Americas==== *in the [[Dominican Republic]]: 4 August 1865 - 15 November 1865, his first non-consecutive presidential term: [[José María Cabral|José María Cabral y de Luna]] (b. 1819 - d. 1899) *in [[Haiti]]: Sylvain Salnave (b. 1826 - d. 1870), one of the three members of the previous Provisional Government, was President 4 May 1867 - 27 December 1869 and ''Protector of the Republic'' to 16 June 1867 *in present [[Nicaragua]]: on 20 April 1823 general [[José Anacleto Ordóñez]] was proclaimed ''General en Jefe del Ejército, Protector y Libertador de Granada''; he acted as head of state (e.g. in a treaty ), but set up a Governing [[military junta|Junta]] (it's unclear whether he was a member) which continued to govern after Granada's accession{{Clarify|November 2009|date=November 2009}} to the [[Central American Federation]] on July 2 *in [[Peru]]: 3 August 1821 - 20 September 1822 general [[José Francisco de San Martín]] y Matorras (b. 1778 - d. 1850) *in the [[Peru-Bolivian Confederation]]: [[Andrés de Santa Cruz y Calahumana|José Andrés de Santa Cruz y Villavicencio y Calumana]] (b. 1792 - d. 1865; Military) '''Supreme Protector''' 28 October 1836 - 20 February 1839 (also [[Bolivia]]n President 24 May 1829 - 20 February 1839) *in [[Brazil]], 12 October 1822 - 15 November 1889, the imperial style was ''Imperador Constitucional e '''Defensor Perpétuo''''' (Constitutional Emperor and '''perpetual defender'''), not unlike the hollow [[victory title]]s of late Roman emperors
===Foreign hegemons===
====Napoleonic France==== *in most of Germany, east of the Rhine, except Prussia, from 25 July 1806 to 19 October 1813, the French Emperor, [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]], bore the additional title of '''''protecteur''' de la Confédération du Rhin'', i.e. Protector of the [[Confederation of the Rhine]], generally known as ''Rheinbund'' ('Rhenan League'), uniting the German princes that had bowed to the conqueror. The actual presidency of its diet and council of Kings was held by a German prince, the [[Fürstprimas]] ('Prince-primate'). *Bonaparte had a similar position in Switzerland (then called the [[Helvetic Republic]]/[[Swiss Confederation (Napoleonic)|Swiss Confederation]]) under French occupation, but there his style was ''Médiateur de la Confédération Helvétique'' (Mediator, 1809 - 31 December 1813), while the chairmanship of the Diet (legislative assembly, since 10 March 1803), the acting Head of the Confederation, with the title ''[[Landammann]] der Schweiz'' {{de icon}}/''Landamman de la Suisse'' {{fr icon}}/''[[Landamano]] della Svizzera'' {{it icon}}, fell simply to the [[chief magistrate]] of the canton hosting it.
====Nazi Germany==== *Nazi Germany was represented by a '''Reichsprotektor''' ('Reich protector') in the Czech puppet-state it installed on 16 March 1939 under the explicit name ''Protektorat Böhmen und Mähren'', the "[[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia]]". (This excluded the ethnically German regions, which were annexed as ''Reichsgau'' [[Sudetenland]].) The Reichsprotektor held the real executive power, not the native President and Prime Minister. The German incumbents, after a month under a Military Governor, were: **5 April 1939 – 20 August 1943 [[Konstantin von Neurath]], ''[[Freiherr]]'' (1873 – 1956) NSDAP **27 September 1941 – 4 June 1942 [[Reinhard Heydrich]] (1904 – 1942) NSDAP (acting for Neurath) **27 May 1942 – 28 May 1942 [[Karl Hermann Frank]] (1898 – 1946) NSDAP (acting for the mortally wounded Heydrich) **28 May 1942 – 14 October 1943 [[Kurt Daluege]] (1897 – 1946) NSDAP (acting [to 5 June 1942] for Heydrich]) **14 October 1943 – 8 May 1945 [[Wilhelm Frick]] (1877 – 1946) NSDAP **26 April 1945 – 8 May 1945 [[Ferdinand Schörner]] (1892 – 1973) (military commander with unrestricted executive power)
====Fictitious==== The self-styled [[Emperor Norton|Emperor Norton I of the United States]] included among his titles "Protector of Mexico."
===Colonial administration=== *In Spanish America, a '''[[Protector of the Indians]]''' was to restrain the abuses of the [[conquistadores]] at the expense of the [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] [[Amerindian|Indios]], e.g. granted to the first missionary [[bishop of Cusco]] (in Peru). *In the British Empire, a colonial official responsible for administering the [[Chinese Protectorate]]s, entities charged with the well-being of [[Chinese race|ethnic Chinese]] residents of the [[United Kingdom|British]]-held [[Straits Settlements]]—which included current-day [[Singapore]]—during that territory's [[Colonialism|colonial]] period. *In the French empire, the ''Protecteur des Indigènes'' 'Protector of the Natives' was a colonial official charged with the protection of an indigenous community; ironically, such 'native' status was also awarded to the (Asian) ''immigrants'' -thus officially named- on the island of [[La Réunion]].
==Religious==
===Catholic=== {{Main|Cardinal protector}} Since the thirteenth century it has been customary at Rome to confide to some particular Cardinal a special solicitude in the [[Roman Curia]] for the interests of a given religious order or institute, confraternity, church, college, city, nation, etc. Such a person is known as a ''Cardinal Protector''.
===Islamic=== The title ''Hâdim ül Haramain ish Sharifain'' or ''Khādim al-Ḥaramayn al-Sharifayn'', Arabic/Turkish for 'Servant of the Noble Sanctuaries', notably [[Mecca]] and [[Medina]] (the destinations of the [[hajj]] pilgrimage; both in the [[Grand Sherif]]'s peninsular Arabian territory; the third being [[Jerusalem]], part of an Ottoman province) was awarded to Ottoman Sultan [[Salim Khan I]] by the Sherif of Mecca in 1517, a year after his conquest of Egypt and assuming of the title of [[Commander of the Faithful]], and [[Successor of the Prophet of the Lord of the Universe]], i.e. Caliph; both remained part of the full style of his successors on the Turkish throne.
==See also== * [[Defensor (disambiguation)|Defensor]] * [[Heavenly protector]] * [[Lord Protector]] (sometimes in the short form Protector) * [[Protectorate]] for the use of the word for a state 'protecting' another political entity * [[Protectorate of Missions]]
